title: Gait Disorder Evaluation
icd10: ** R26.9 (Unspecified abnormalities of gait and mobility)
R26.89 (Other abnormalities of gait and mobility)
scope: ** Systematic evaluation of gait disorders in adults presenting with new or progressive difficulty walking. Covers neurological gait patterns: spastic (UMN), ataxic (cerebellar and sensory), parkinsonian/festinating, neuropathic/steppage, myopathic/waddling, frontal/apraxic (NPH), and functional gait disorders. Includes laboratory, imaging, and electrodiagnostic evaluation to identify etiology. Covers treatment of reversible causes (B12 deficiency, NPH, compressive myelopathy, inflammatory conditions). Excludes orthopedic/mechanical gait disorders as primary diagnosis but includes in differential. Excludes isolated vertigo/dizziness evaluation (see separate plan if available).

Core Labs (All Patients).rationale: Electrolyte abnormalities (hyponatremia, hypocalcemia); renal/hepatic dysfunction; glucose
Hypothyroidism causing cerebellar ataxia, neuropathy, or myopathy; hyperthyroidism causing myopathy
B12 deficiency causing subacute combined degeneration (dorsal column + corticospinal tract); sensory ataxia; TREATABLE
Elevated in functional B12 deficiency even when B12 borderline normal (200-400 pg/mL)
Diabetic neuropathy (sensory ataxic gait); diabetic foot complications
Folate deficiency contributing to myelopathy or neuropathy
Hypomagnesemia causing ataxia, weakness; often missed
Neurosyphilis (tabes dorsalis): sensory ataxic gait, Argyll Robertson pupils, lightning pains
Vitamin E deficiency causing spinocerebellar syndrome with ataxia and neuropathy; fat malabsorption

Extended Labs (Based on Gait Pattern and.rationale: Copper deficiency myelopathy mimics B12 deficiency (subacute combined degeneration); zinc excess, bariatric surgery
Wilson disease (if age <50): dystonic or parkinsonian gait, hepatic disease
Elevated in Wilson disease; >100 µg/24h suggestive
HIV-associated vacuolar myelopathy; HIV neuropathy; cerebellar ataxia

Extended Labs (Based on Gait Pattern and.item: Paraneoplastic antibody panel (anti-Yo, anti-Hu, anti-Tr/DNER, anti-mGluR1, anti-VGCC)
Extended Labs (Based on Gait Pattern and.rationale: Paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration: subacute progressive cerebellar ataxia; anti-Yo (ovarian, breast), anti-Hu (SCLC)
GAD65-associated cerebellar ataxia; stiff-person spectrum; autoimmune
Gluten ataxia: progressive cerebellar ataxia; may occur without GI symptoms; TREATABLE with gluten-free diet
Alcoholic cerebellar degeneration (vermis); peripheral neuropathy; Wernicke encephalopathy
Wernicke encephalopathy: acute ataxia, ophthalmoplegia, encephalopathy; TREAT EMPIRICALLY before results
Autoimmune conditions (SLE, Sjögren) causing myelopathy, neuropathy, or CNS vasculitis
Paraproteinemic neuropathy; myeloma causing cord compression; anti-MAG neuropathy
Hereditary ataxias if progressive cerebellar syndrome without acquired cause; FXN GAA repeats for Friedreich; SCA1/2/3/6/7 repeat expansions

Lumbar Puncture (Selected Cases).rationale: Elevated in NPH (though often normal on single LP); intracranial hypertension
Elevated protein: inflammation, infection, GBS; pleocytosis: infection, carcinomatous meningitis
Lumbar Puncture (Selected Cases).target: Normal protein (<45 mg/dL); <5 WBC; normal glucose

Lumbar Puncture (Selected Cases).rationale: Neurosyphilis (tabes dorsalis); specific but not sensitive
Carcinomatous/lymphomatous meningitis causing polyradiculopathy or myelopathy
Prion disease (CJD): rapidly progressive ataxia with dementia and myoclonus
Therapeutic/diagnostic trial for NPH: assess gait improvement pre and post drainage (timed up-and-go, 10-meter walk); positive response predicts shunt responsiveness
Lumbar Puncture (Selected Cases).target: Gait improvement within 24-72 hours of drainage supports NPH

Core Imaging.rationale: Cerebellar lesion (stroke, tumor, abscess, MS plaque); NPH (ventriculomegaly out of proportion to atrophy); white matter disease (vascular, demyelinating); basal ganglia pathology
Cervical myelopathy (spondylotic, tumor, demyelinating): most common treatable cause of spastic gait; cord compression, signal change
Core Imaging.target: No cord compression or signal abnormality

Core Imaging.rationale: Thoracic myelopathy (tumor, transverse myelitis, vascular malformation, epidural abscess); B12 deficiency (dorsal column T2 signal)
Core Imaging.target: No cord compression or signal abnormality

Core Imaging.rationale: Lumbar stenosis (neurogenic claudication); cauda equina syndrome; polyradiculopathy
Acute presentation: stroke, hemorrhage, mass; also screens for hydrocephalus (NPH) before LP

Advanced Imaging.rationale: NPH: assess CSF dynamics when diagnosis uncertain; delayed clearance and ventricular reflux support NPH
Research/advanced: quantify cerebellar atrophy (MSA-C, SCA); white matter tract integrity; distinguish NPH from atrophy
Distinguish parkinsonian gait (reduced dopamine transporter uptake) from vascular parkinsonism, NPH, or drug-induced parkinsonism (normal DaTscan)
Paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration: identify occult malignancy (ovarian, breast, lung, lymphoma)
Vertebrobasilar insufficiency causing episodic ataxia; dural AV fistula causing myelopathy
Spinal dural arteriovenous fistula (dAVF): progressive myelopathy; MRI may show flow voids, cord edema

Electrodiagnostic and Functional Studies.rationale: Peripheral neuropathy (sensory ataxic, steppage gait); polyradiculopathy; motor neuron disease; myopathy
Dorsal column dysfunction (sensory ataxic gait); subclinical myelopathy; complement MRI findings
MS evaluation if demyelinating myelopathy suspected; subclinical optic nerve involvement
Objective gait parameters (velocity, cadence, stride length, variability); research/specialized centers; useful for NPH pre/post shunt assessment
Orthostatic hypotension contributing to gait instability/falls; MSA (cerebellar ataxia + autonomic failure)
Epileptic gait disorder (drop attacks, tonic seizures); CJD (periodic sharp wave complexes with rapid ataxia)

Acute/Reversible Causes.indication: Wernicke encephalopathy (acute ataxia, ophthalmoplegia, confusion); treat EMPIRICALLY if suspected — do NOT wait for levels

dosing.instructions: 500 mg IV TID for 3-5 days, then 250 mg IV daily for 3-5 days, then 100 mg PO daily indefinitely

Acute/Reversible Causes.monitoring: Clinical response (ataxia, ophthalmoplegia improve first); administer BEFORE glucose

Acute/Reversible Causes.indication: B12 deficiency with myelopathy or neuropathy (subacute combined degeneration)

dosing.instructions: 1000 mcg IM daily for 7 days, then weekly for 4 weeks, then monthly indefinitely; alternatively high-dose oral 1000-2000 mcg daily for mild cases

Acute/Reversible Causes.monitoring: B12 levels at 2-3 months; MMA normalization; clinical improvement (sensory may improve; motor/spastic deficits less reversible)

Acute/Reversible Causes.item: VP shunt / ETV (ventriculoperitoneal shunt / endoscopic third ventriculostomy)
Acute/Reversible Causes.indication: Normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) with positive large-volume LP trial or consistent clinical/radiographic features (Hakim triad, Evans index >0.3, DESH)

doseOptions.orderSentence: VP shunt / ETV (ventriculoperitoneal shunt / endoscopic third ventriculostomy) Neurosurgical evaluation Surgical

dosing.instructions: Programmable valve preferred; gait improvement is best predictor of shunt response; earlier shunting associated with better outcomes
dosing.orderSentence: VP shunt / ETV (ventriculoperitoneal shunt / endoscopic third ventriculostomy) Neurosurgical evaluation Surgical

Acute/Reversible Causes.monitoring: Post-shunt: serial imaging; valve adjustments; monitor for over-drainage (subdural collections), infection, obstruction; gait reassessment at 3 and 6 months

Acute/Reversible Causes.indication: Compressive myelopathy (cervical spondylotic myelopathy, tumor, epidural abscess)

doseOptions.orderSentence: Surgical decompression (cervical/thoracic) Neurosurgical/orthopedic spine evaluation Surgical

dosing.instructions: Anterior cervical discectomy/fusion (ACDF), laminoplasty, or laminectomy based on pathology and alignment
dosing.orderSentence: Surgical decompression (cervical/thoracic) Neurosurgical/orthopedic spine evaluation Surgical

Acute/Reversible Causes.monitoring: Post-operative neurological exam; MRI at 3-6 months; rehabilitation

Acute/Reversible Causes.indication: Acute inflammatory myelopathy (MS relapse, NMOSD, transverse myelitis, neurosarcoidosis)

dosing.instructions: 1000 mg IV daily for 3-5 days; followed by oral prednisone taper if indicated

Acute/Reversible Causes.contraindications: Active untreated infection; uncontrolled diabetes; GI bleeding
Acute/Reversible Causes.monitoring: Blood glucose Q6H on steroids; GI prophylaxis; blood pressure; infection surveillance

Acute/Reversible Causes.indication: Gluten ataxia (positive anti-gliadin antibodies with cerebellar ataxia and no alternative cause)

doseOptions.orderSentence: Gluten-free diet Strict gluten-free diet Dietary

dosing.instructions: Lifelong gluten elimination; may take 6-12 months for maximal improvement; refer to dietitian
dosing.orderSentence: Gluten-free diet Strict gluten-free diet Dietary

Acute/Reversible Causes.monitoring: Anti-gliadin antibody titers (should decline); clinical ataxia assessment every 3-6 months; cerebellar MRI

doseOptions.orderSentence: D-penicillamine or trientine Trientine 250 mg PO

dosing.instructions: Trientine preferred for neurological Wilson (less risk of paradoxical worsening vs D-penicillamine); zinc maintenance after de-coppering
dosing.orderSentence: D-penicillamine or trientine Trientine 250 mg PO

Acute/Reversible Causes.monitoring: 24-hour urine copper; free copper levels; LFTs; CBC; neurological status (watch for paradoxical worsening)

dosing.instructions: 18-24 million units/day IV for 10-14 days

Acute/Reversible Causes.monitoring: CSF VDRL and cell count at 6-month intervals post-treatment until normalized; serum RPR decline

dosing.instructions: Start 25/100 mg TID with meals; titrate by 25/100 mg increments every 3-7 days to clinical effect; robust response supports PD diagnosis

Symptomatic Treatment — Parkinsonian & S.monitoring: Dyskinesias; motor fluctuations (wearing off); orthostatic hypotension; impulse control; nausea

dosing.instructions: 100 mg BID; may increase to 100 mg TID; also treats levodopa-induced dyskinesias

Symptomatic Treatment — Parkinsonian & S.contraindications: Renal impairment (dose adjust); seizure history; livedo reticularis
Symptomatic Treatment — Parkinsonian & S.monitoring: Renal function; hallucinations; livedo reticularis; peripheral edema; confusion in elderly

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg TID, increase by 5 mg every 3 days; max 80 mg/day; caution in elderly

Symptomatic Treatment — Parkinsonian & S.contraindications: Withdrawal seizures if abruptly discontinued; sedation
Symptomatic Treatment — Parkinsonian & S.monitoring: Sedation; weakness (excess dose reduces functional spasticity that aids standing/walking); withdrawal risk

Symptomatic Treatment — Parkinsonian & S.indication: Spastic gait (alternative or adjunct to baclofen)

dosing.instructions: Start 2 mg at bedtime, increase by 2 mg every 3-4 days; max 36 mg/day divided TID

Symptomatic Treatment — Parkinsonian & S.contraindications: Hepatic impairment; concurrent CYP1A2 inhibitors (ciprofloxacin, fluvoxamine)
Symptomatic Treatment — Parkinsonian & S.monitoring: LFTs at baseline and 1, 3, 6 months; sedation; hypotension; dry mouth

Symptomatic Treatment — Parkinsonian & S.indication: Severe spasticity refractory to oral agents; functional impairment despite maximal oral therapy

doseOptions.orderSentence: Intrathecal baclofen pump ITB trial first Intrathecal

dosing.instructions: Baclofen trial via LP (50-100 mcg bolus); if positive response, surgical pump placement; dose titrated by programmer
dosing.orderSentence: Intrathecal baclofen pump ITB trial first Intrathecal

Symptomatic Treatment — Parkinsonian & S.contraindications: Infection at pump site; unable to maintain follow-up for refills
Symptomatic Treatment — Parkinsonian & S.monitoring: Pump refills every 1-6 months; alarm for low volume; withdrawal is medical emergency (hyperthermia, rhabdomyolysis, death)

Symptomatic Treatment — Parkinsonian & S.indication: Focal spasticity (ankle plantar flexor spasticity causing equinovarus foot; hip adductor spasticity)

dosing.instructions: Dose depends on muscle group; gastrocnemius/soleus 200-400 units; posterior tibialis 100-200 units; adductors 200-400 units; repeat every 12 weeks

Symptomatic Treatment — Parkinsonian & S.contraindications: Myasthenia gravis; infection at injection site
Symptomatic Treatment — Parkinsonian & S.monitoring: Effect onset 3-7 days; peak 2-4 weeks; duration 12 weeks; monitor for excessive weakness; functional gait assessment pre/post

Symptomatic Treatment — Cerebellar Ataxi.indication: Gait impairment in MS (FDA-approved); cerebellar ataxia (off-label, limited evidence)

dosing.instructions: 10 mg BID (12 hours apart); extended-release formulation

Symptomatic Treatment — Cerebellar Ataxi.contraindications: Seizure history (lowers threshold); renal impairment (CrCl <50 — contraindicated); concurrent 4-AP compounded formulations
Symptomatic Treatment — Cerebellar Ataxi.monitoring: Seizure risk; renal function; timed 25-foot walk (assess response); discontinue if no benefit by 2 weeks

Symptomatic Treatment — Cerebellar Ataxi.indication: Cerebellar ataxia (SCA, off-label); limited evidence from RCT showing modest benefit

dosing.instructions: 50 mg BID; based on Ristori et al 2010 RCT showing SARA score improvement in mixed cerebellar ataxias

Symptomatic Treatment — Cerebellar Ataxi.monitoring: LFTs at baseline, monthly for 3 months, then periodically; SARA score; clinical response

Symptomatic Treatment — Cerebellar Ataxi.indication: Episodic ataxia type 2 (EA2, CACNA1A mutation); effective prophylaxis for ataxic episodes

dosing.instructions: Start 250 mg BID; increase to 500 mg BID as tolerated

Symptomatic Treatment — Cerebellar Ataxi.contraindications: Sulfa allergy; severe renal/hepatic disease; hypokalemia
Symptomatic Treatment — Cerebellar Ataxi.monitoring: BMP (metabolic acidosis, hypokalemia); renal stones; paresthesias; fatigue

Symptomatic Treatment — Cerebellar Ataxi.indication: ALL gait disorders — cornerstone of management regardless of etiology

doseOptions.orderSentence: Physical therapy (balance/gait training) PT evaluation and gait training Rehab

dosing.instructions: Balance exercises, gait retraining, compensatory strategies, assistive device training; vestibular rehabilitation if vestibular component
dosing.orderSentence: Physical therapy (balance/gait training) PT evaluation and gait training Rehab

Symptomatic Treatment — Cerebellar Ataxi.monitoring: Timed up-and-go; Berg Balance Scale; 10-meter walk test; fall frequency

doseOptions.orderSentence: Assistive devices (cane, walker, rollator, wheelchair) PT assessment for appropriate device Device

dosing.instructions: Single-point cane for mild instability; rollator walker for moderate; wheelchair for severe or fatigable gait; properly fitted
dosing.orderSentence: Assistive devices (cane, walker, rollator, wheelchair) PT assessment for appropriate device Device

Supportive Measures & Fall Prevention.monitoring: Reassess need as condition progresses or improves; ensure proper fitting and training

Supportive Measures & Fall Prevention.indication: Fall prevention in all gait disorders

doseOptions.orderSentence: Home safety evaluation (OT) OT home safety assessment Rehab

dosing.instructions: Remove trip hazards; install grab bars, handrails; adequate lighting; shower bench; medical alert device
dosing.orderSentence: Home safety evaluation (OT) OT home safety assessment Rehab

Supportive Measures & Fall Prevention.monitoring: Fall diary; reassess home modifications as function changes

doseOptions.orderSentence: Ankle-foot orthoses (AFOs) Custom or off-the-shelf AFOs Device

dosing.instructions: Fitted by orthotist; articulated preferred if ankle dorsiflexion present
dosing.orderSentence: Ankle-foot orthoses (AFOs) Custom or off-the-shelf AFOs Device

Supportive Measures & Fall Prevention.monitoring: Skin checks; functional benefit; replace as needed

Supportive Measures & Fall Prevention.indication: Fall prevention (if deficient); bone health in patients at fall risk

dosing.instructions: 1000-2000 IU daily maintenance; 50000 IU weekly for 8-12 weeks if deficient (<20 ng/mL)

Supportive Measures & Fall Prevention.indication: Fall risk assessment — fracture prevention; especially in chronic gait disorders with recurrent falls

doseOptions.orderSentence: DEXA scan / osteoporosis management DEXA scan Imaging

dosing.instructions: Treat osteoporosis per guidelines; bisphosphonates, denosumab as indicated
dosing.orderSentence: DEXA scan / osteoporosis management DEXA scan Imaging

Supportive Measures & Fall Prevention.monitoring: T-score; fracture risk (FRAX); calcium and vitamin D adequacy

Supportive Measures & Fall Prevention.indication: ALL gait disorders — review and minimize medications contributing to gait impairment or falls

doseOptions.orderSentence: Medication review (deprescribing) Systematic medication review Clinical

dosing.instructions: Taper/discontinue: benzodiazepines, anticholinergics, sedating antihistamines, opioids, alpha-blockers, centrally acting antihypertensives
dosing.orderSentence: Medication review (deprescribing) Systematic medication review Clinical

Supportive Measures & Fall Prevention.monitoring: Fall frequency; orthostatic vitals; cognitive function; balance assessment

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology consultation for gait disorder localization (spastic vs ataxic vs parkinsonian vs neuropathic vs functional) and directed workup
Neurosurgery referral for NPH (positive large-volume LP trial), cervical myelopathy with cord compression, spinal tumor, or spinal dural AV fistula
Physical therapy for gait retraining, balance exercises (vestibular and proprioceptive), fall prevention program, and assistive device fitting
Occupational therapy for home safety evaluation, ADL modification, adaptive equipment, and fall hazard assessment
Speech therapy for dysphagia evaluation if cerebellar ataxia with dysarthria or brainstem involvement affecting swallow
Movement disorders specialist referral for parkinsonian gait not responding to levodopa, suspected MSA or PSP, or tremor-predominant presentations
Orthopedic spine surgery consultation for lumbar stenosis with neurogenic claudication or cervical spondylotic myelopathy requiring surgical decision
Orthotics referral for ankle-foot orthoses (foot drop/steppage gait), shoe modifications, or custom bracing
Genetic counseling for suspected hereditary ataxia (SCA, Friedreich, HSP), hereditary neuropathy (CMT), or Wilson disease — discuss family implications
Psychiatry referral for functional gait disorder (multidisciplinary approach: CBT, physical rehabilitation, psychoeducation)
Oncology referral for paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration with positive antibodies or identified malignancy on PET-CT
Dietitian referral for gluten-free diet implementation (gluten ataxia), nutritional optimization (B12/thiamine/folate deficiency), or weight management
Social work for disability resources, home care services, adaptive equipment funding, and caregiver support in progressive gait disorders
Palliative care referral for advanced progressive gait disorders (MSA-C, advanced SCA, ALS) for symptom management and goals of care

Patient Instructions.item: Return immediately for sudden inability to walk, new leg weakness, or loss of bladder/bowel control (may indicate cord compression or stroke requiring emergency treatment)
Return immediately for acute onset of ataxia with headache, vomiting, or altered consciousness (may indicate cerebellar stroke or hemorrhage)
Return immediately for new double vision, facial weakness, slurred speech, or numbness (may indicate brainstem or posterior circulation stroke)
Use prescribed assistive device (cane, walker, rollator) at all times when walking; do not walk unsupported until cleared by physical therapy
Remove tripping hazards at home (loose rugs, clutter, cords); install grab bars in bathroom and handrails on all stairs; ensure adequate lighting
Do not drive until formally cleared by neurology — gait disorder may indicate broader neurological impairment affecting driving safety
Keep a fall diary recording date, time, circumstances, and any injuries from each fall to guide treatment decisions at follow-up visits
Take all medications as prescribed; do not stop Parkinson medications, spasticity medications, or supplements (B12, thiamine) without physician guidance
For gluten ataxia: strictly avoid all wheat, barley, rye, and cross-contaminated products; improvement may take 6-12 months of strict adherence
Wear non-slip footwear at all times; avoid walking in socks, slippers, or bare feet on smooth surfaces
If prescribed AFOs (ankle braces), wear them during all walking activities and check skin daily for redness or breakdown

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Alcohol cessation — alcohol worsens cerebellar function, causes cerebellar degeneration (vermian atrophy), and increases fall risk
Regular exercise program adapted to balance limitations (swimming, stationary cycling, seated exercises, tai chi) to maintain strength and reduce fall risk
Fall prevention strategies: adequate home lighting, non-skid footwear, remove loose rugs, install handrails on both sides of stairs, shower bench
Vitamin D supplementation (1000-2000 IU daily) and calcium for bone health given chronic fall risk; treat deficiency aggressively
Maintain healthy weight to reduce joint stress, improve mobility, and lower cardiovascular risk contributing to vascular gait disorders
Strict glycemic control (HbA1c <7%) if diabetic neuropathy contributing to sensory ataxic gait or fall risk
Mediterranean or balanced diet rich in B12 (meat, fish, dairy), folate (leafy greens), and thiamine to support nerve health
Adequate sleep (7-9 hours nightly) — fatigue worsens gait instability and increases fall risk in all neurological gait disorders
Medical alert bracelet recommended for patients with episodic ataxia (may appear intoxicated during episodes) or conditions causing sudden falls

differential.features: Spastic gait; upper motor neuron signs (hyperreflexia, Babinski, Hoffmann); neck pain/stiffness; hand clumsiness; most common cause of myelopathy in adults >55
differential.tests: MRI cervical spine (cord compression, T2 signal change)

differential.features: Hakim triad: gait apraxia (magnetic gait) + urinary incontinence + dementia; wide-based short steps; ventriculomegaly disproportionate to atrophy
differential.tests: MRI brain (Evans index >0.3, DESH); large-volume LP trial (gait improvement)

differential.features: Shuffling, festinating gait; decreased arm swing (often asymmetric); rest tremor; rigidity; bradykinesia; excellent levodopa response
differential.tests: Clinical (MDS criteria); DaTscan (reduced uptake); levodopa response

differential.features: Spastic and/or ataxic gait; relapsing-remitting history; young adults; optic neuritis, internuclear ophthalmoplegia
differential.tests: MRI brain/spine (demyelinating lesions); CSF OCBs; VEPs

differential.features: Sensory ataxic gait; positive Romberg; loss of vibration/proprioception; dorsal column + corticospinal tract involvement; macrocytic anemia
differential.tests: B12 level (<200 pg/mL); MMA (elevated); MRI spine (dorsal column T2 signal)

differential.features: Acute ataxic gait; headache, vertigo, nausea; ipsilateral cerebellar signs; may progress to brainstem compression
Progressive spastic gait; family history; onset childhood-to-adult; "pure" vs "complex" forms; slowly progressive
differential.tests: Genetic testing (SPG4/spastin most common); MRI (thoracic cord atrophy); NCS normal; clinical diagnosis

differential.features: Progressive cerebellar ataxia; family history (AD); additional features vary by subtype (SCA1: brainstem, SCA3: peripheral neuropathy, SCA6: pure cerebellar)
differential.tests: Genetic testing (trinucleotide repeat expansion panel: SCA1/2/3/6/7/17); MRI (cerebellar +/- brainstem atrophy)

differential.features: Subacute progressive cerebellar ataxia; may precede cancer diagnosis by months-years; anti-Yo (gynecological), anti-Hu (SCLC), anti-Tr (Hodgkin)
differential.tests: Paraneoplastic antibody panel; PET-CT (occult malignancy); CSF (pleocytosis, OCBs)

differential.features: Inconsistent gait pattern; distractibility; knee buckling without falling; astasia-abasia; Hoover sign positive; entrainment
differential.tests: Clinical examination (inconsistency, distractibility); normal investigations; positive signs (Hoover, entrainment)

differential.features: Gait worsens with walking (claudication) and extension; improves with flexion (shopping cart sign); leg pain, numbness, weakness with ambulation
differential.tests: MRI lumbar spine (central canal stenosis); clinical history (positional symptoms)

differential.features: Stocking-glove sensory loss; areflexia; steppage gait (foot drop) or sensory ataxic gait; length-dependent pattern
differential.tests: NCS/EMG; B12, HbA1c, SPEP; directed testing per neuropathy evaluation

differential.features: Progressive cerebellar ataxia + autonomic failure (orthostatic hypotension, urinary dysfunction); poor levodopa response; rapid progression
differential.tests: MRI brain (cerebellar/pontine atrophy, "hot cross bun" sign); autonomic testing; DaTscan (may be abnormal)

evidence.evidenceLevel: Pirker W, Katzenschlager R. Gait disorders in adults and the elderly: A clinical guide. Wien Klin Wochenschr. 2017;129(3-4):81-95.
evidence.source: Comprehensive review of gait disorder classification, clinical features, and diagnostic approach in adults

evidence.evidenceLevel: Snijders AH, van de Warrenburg BP, Giladi N, Bloem BR. Neurological gait disorders in elderly people: clinical approach and classification. Lancet Neurol. 2007;6(1):63-74.
evidence.source: Systematic classification of neurological gait disorders; diagnostic algorithm based on gait pattern recognition

evidence.evidenceLevel: Williams DR, Watt HC, Lees AJ. Predictors of falls and fractures in bradykinetic rigid syndromes: a retrospective study. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry. 2006;77(4):468-473.
evidence.source: Falls in parkinsonian disorders; gait freezing and postural instability are strongest predictors of falls

evidence.evidenceLevel: Relkin N, Marmarou A, Klinge P, et al. Diagnosing idiopathic normal-pressure hydrocephalus. Neurosurgery. 2005;57(3 Suppl):S4-16.
evidence.source: International NPH guidelines: diagnostic criteria, CSF tap test, supplementary tests; gait improvement best predicts shunt response

evidence.evidenceLevel: Healton EB, Savage DG, Brust JC, et al. Neurologic aspects of cobalamin deficiency. Medicine (Baltimore). 1991;70(4):229-245.
evidence.source: Classic series on B12 deficiency neurological manifestations; gait ataxia in 18% at presentation; treatment prevents progression

evidence.evidenceLevel: Hadjivassiliou M, et al. Gluten ataxia in perspective: epidemiology, genetic susceptibility and clinical characteristics. Brain. 2003;126(Pt 3):685-691.
evidence.source: Gluten ataxia accounts for ~15% of sporadic cerebellar ataxias; anti-gliadin antibody testing recommended in all idiopathic ataxias

evidence.evidenceLevel: Goodman AD, et al. Sustained-release oral fampridine in multiple sclerosis: a randomised, double-blind, controlled trial. Lancet. 2009;373(9665):732-738.
evidence.source: Dalfampridine (4-AP) improved walking speed in MS (timed 25-foot walk responder analysis); first FDA-approved treatment for walking impairment in MS

evidence.evidenceLevel: Ristori G, et al. Riluzole in cerebellar ataxia: a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled pilot trial. Neurology. 2010;74(10):839-845.
evidence.source: Riluzole improved SARA score in mixed cerebellar ataxias (hereditary and sporadic) over 8 weeks vs placebo

evidence.evidenceLevel: Montero-Odasso M, et al. World guidelines for falls prevention and management for older adults: a global initiative. Age Ageing. 2022;51(9):afac205.
evidence.source: Evidence-based guidelines for fall risk assessment and multifactorial fall prevention; exercise and medication review most effective interventions

evidence.evidenceLevel: Nonnekes J, et al. Functional gait disorders: A sign-based approach. Neurology. 2020;94(24):1093-1099.
evidence.source: Diagnostic signs for functional gait disorders; positive clinical signs (inconsistency, distractibility, Hoover) enable confident diagnosis

monitoring.action: Fall prevention program; assistive device; PT intensification
PT referral; investigate worsening; assistive device
<45: moderate risk; <36: high risk → intensify fall prevention
Medication review; PT; home safety; assistive device; investigate new etiology
>20% worsening: reassess MS therapy; consider dalfampridine trial
Investigate new etiologies; adjust treatment; PT modification
Refer pulmonary if <80%; consider NIV if <50%; intubate if <20 mL/kg or declining rapidly

monitoring.item: B12 / nutritional levels (B12, MMA, folate, copper, thiamine)
monitoring.frequency: At baseline; repeat at 3 months if supplementing
Baseline; repeat based on etiology (6-12 months for active disease)
q6h during IV steroids; QID during oral taper
monitoring.action: >200 → sliding scale insulin; endocrinology if persistent

monitoring.item: Renal function (on dalfampridine, medications cleared renally)
monitoring.action: CrCl <50 → discontinue dalfampridine; adjust renally-cleared medications

disposition.criteria: Stable chronic gait disorder with no acute change; no cord compression; no acute cerebellar stroke; falls without serious injury and adequate home support

Acute gait deterioration (new inability to walk); cord compression requiring urgent surgery; acute cerebellar stroke/hemorrhage; Wernicke encephalopathy; GBS; new-onset myelopathy; falls with serious injury; unsafe discharge (unable to ambulate safely at home)
Subacute gait worsening requiring expedited workup (MRI, LP); falls in elderly requiring multifactorial assessment; NPH large-volume LP trial
All new gait disorders for systematic evaluation; chronic gait disorders for longitudinal monitoring
NPH (positive LP trial); cervical myelopathy with cord compression; tumor; spinal dural AV fistula
Significant gait impairment requiring intensive multidisciplinary rehabilitation
Any gait disorder suggesting broader neurological impairment affecting driving safety
